response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "This measure appropriates funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and establishes a supportive housing special fund to be administered by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [CHUNK_15] The bill aims to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects for individuals and families with special needs. [CHUNK_16] Language that would have established a separate Kauhale Initiative Special Fund was deleted by the committee. [CHUNK_60]",
  "appropriations": "The bill was amended to make all appropriations unspecified amounts. [CHUNK_59] However, the Committee on Human Services & Homelessness requested that the Committee on Finance consider an appropriation of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative. [CHUNK_62, NUMBER_5] The committee also requested consideration of $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) to be deposited into the Supportive Housing Special Fund, with $11,810,250 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for projects and $189,750 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for one temporary FTE position. [CHUNK_62, CHUNK_63, NUMBER_6, NUMBER_7, NUMBER_8]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The provided documents do not specify the methodology used to derive the suggested appropriation amounts. [CHUNK_62] The fiscal plan is based on the finding that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation and that continued efforts are needed. [CHUNK_55] The appropriations are intended to fund the Kauhale Initiative and create a new financing tool for supportive housing to address this issue. [CHUNK_15, CHUNK_24]",
  "agency_impact": "The Hawaii housing finance and development corporation will be responsible for administering the new supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_27] This includes establishing one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help with its administration. [CHUNK_26, CHUNK_41] The office of the governor is designated to expend the appropriations for the kauhale initiative and may transfer funds to other agencies like the statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions. [CHUNK_19, CHUNK_20]",
  "economic_impact": "This measure represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawaii's most vulnerable populations. [CHUNK_56] It enables the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. [CHUNK_57] The measure also supports efforts to build partnerships between government and the community to create an effective and efficient system for developers and service providers. [CHUNK_57]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act amends Chapter 201H, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by adding a new subpart to establish the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_27] It also establishes one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position within the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [CHUNK_26] Language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund was deleted in the amended version of the bill. [CHUNK_60]",
  "revenue_sources": "Appropriations for the kauhale initiative and the deposit into the new special fund are from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_17, CHUNK_38] The supportive housing special fund may also include private contributions, proceeds from repayment of loans, interest, fees, other returns, and moneys from other sources. [CHUNK_30] A proposed Kauhale Initiative Special Fund, which would have been another revenue vehicle, was deleted from the measure. [CHUNK_60]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The bill as amended contains unspecified appropriations for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_17, CHUNK_38, CHUNK_59] The Committee on Human Services & Homelessness requested that the Committee on Finance consider an appropriation of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative for each of the two fiscal years. [CHUNK_62, NUMBER_5] The committee also requested consideration of a deposit of $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) into the Supportive Housing Special Fund for each of the two fiscal years. [CHUNK_62, NUMBER_6] Out of the special fund, the committee recommended expending $11,810,250 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the financing of supportive housing projects and $189,750 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for one temporary 1.0 FTE position. [CHUNK_63, CHUNK_64, NUMBER_7, NUMBER_8] A significant change from any prior version is the deletion of language that attempted to prevent the proper lapse of the general fund appropriation at the end of the fiscal biennium. [CHUNK_59] No fiscal information beyond the two-year period is provided. [CHUNK_17, CHUNK_38]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The Hawaii housing finance and development corporation is authorized to establish, revise, charge, and collect a reasonable service fee in connection with its financing and services under the supportive housing program. [CHUNK_35] These fees are to be deposited into the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_35] A provision for a Kauhale Initiative Special Fund, which may have included program revenues, was deleted from the bill. [CHUNK_60]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "Moneys in the supportive housing special fund may be used to make loans to finance the development, pre-development, construction, acquisition, preservation, or substantial rehabilitation of supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_28] The fund can also be used for project-based rental assistance payments and payments for supportive services. [CHUNK_29] No specific capital projects are identified for the current appropriation request. [CHUNK_40]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The establishment of the permanent supportive housing special fund indicates an ongoing fiscal commitment beyond the initial biennium. [CHUNK_27] This fund is designed to receive future sums appropriated by the legislature, private contributions, and other moneys to continue its purpose. [CHUNK_30] The continued implementation of the kauhale initiative will likely require future general fund appropriations in subsequent biennia. [CHUNK_17, CHUNK_18]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "Compared to the previous fiscal note, several key changes were made to the bill. [CHUNK_59] First, the bill was amended by changing all appropriations to unspecified amounts. [CHUNK_59] Second, language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund was deleted. [CHUNK_60] Third, language preventing the general fund appropriation from lapsing at the end of the fiscal biennium was also deleted. [CHUNK_59] Finally, the effective dates were changed to June 29, 3000, and July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_61]",
  "fte_positions": "The bill establishes one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I within the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [CHUNK_41] This position is intended to help with the administration of the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_26, CHUNK_41] The Committee on Human Services & Homelessness requested that the Committee on Finance consider an appropriation amount of $189,750 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the position. [CHUNK_63, CHUNK_64, NUMBER_8]",
  "appropriations_changes": "The primary change is that the committee has amended this measure by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts. [CHUNK_59] This differs from any prior version of the bill that may have contained specific dollar figures. [CHUNK_59] The Committee on Human Services & Homelessness has requested that the Committee on Finance consider specific figures, including $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_62, NUMBER_5, NUMBER_6]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "The method of funding for the primary appropriations remains the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_17, CHUNK_38] A major change in the bill's funding structure is the deletion of language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund. [CHUNK_60] This removes a dedicated special fund that would have served as a separate funding vehicle for that initiative. [CHUNK_60]",
  "department_impact": "The department responsibilities remain largely the same, with the office of the governor expending funds for the Kauhale Initiative and the Hawaii Housing finance and development corporation expending funds from the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_19, CHUNK_42] However, the deletion of the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund removes the direct responsibility of administering that specific fund from the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing. [CHUNK_60]",
  "reports_required": "The Hawaii housing finance and development corporation is required to submit a report to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of each regular session. [CHUNK_36] The report must describe the projects funded using moneys from the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_36] A reporting requirement tied to the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund is no longer applicable as the fund's establishment was deleted from the measure. [CHUNK_60]",
  "pilot_program": "This bill does not establish a new pilot program. [CHUNK_5] Instead, it provides continued funding for the kauhale initiative, which is an evolution of previous pilot programs like the ohana zones pilot program established in 2018. [CHUNK_3, CHUNK_11] The bill makes the financing mechanism for supportive housing permanent by establishing the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_27]",
  "sunset_date": "The bill does not contain a sunset date for the programs or the special fund established. [CHUNK_48]",
  "effective_date": "This Act shall take effect on June 29, 3000. [CHUNK_48] The committee report notes this date was chosen to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_61] Sections 2, 5, and 6, which relate to appropriations, shall take effect on July 1, 3000. [CHUNK_48]"
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB431 HD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 431 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 1 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate

The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui

with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered,

on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session

county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable

public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session

pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to

$5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically

developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units

was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment,

unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of

for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time-limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long-term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among

targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the important principles of the State's kauhale initiative is building partnerships between government and community, providing affordable spaces for housing and healing, and fostering belonging and responsibility. Every kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding

a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. The legislature also finds that to ensure there is capacity within the State to meet the needs for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is

solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued

this Act is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued implementation of the kauhale initiative; (2) Create the supportive housing special fund to assist the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects in which some or all the units are targeted to

in which some or all the units are targeted to special needs individuals or families who require supportive services; and (3) Appropriate funds to assist the statewide office of homelessness and housing solutions to implement the kauhale initiative. PART II SECTION 2. There is appropriated out of the general revenues

SECTION 2. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued

may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative, including expenses related to the development and operation of kauhale, provision of project-based rent supplement payments, provision of support services for qualified individuals and families in kauhale, and staffing and related costs to administer the

in kauhale, and staffing and related costs to administer the kauhale initiative . The sums appropriated shall be expended by the office of the governor for the purposes of this Act. Notwithstanding any other law to the contrary, the governor may transfer all or a portion of the appropriation in

may transfer all or a portion of the appropriation in this part to the governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies, including the statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions, for expenditures incurred to implement the program. The governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies may expend any appropriation transferred

executive branch departments or agencies may expend any appropriation transferred pursuant to this part for the performance of their duties under the kauhale initiative. PART III SECTION 3. The legislature finds that combining affordable housing with access to services to help special needs populations, such as individuals with alcohol or

help special needs populations, such as individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals, live more stable and productive lives. The legislature further

individuals, live more stable and productive lives. The legislature further finds that the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation administers various programs to finance mixed-income rental housing developments. Creating a new financing tool specifically for supportive housing will enable the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development

Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of supportive housing units in stand-alone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. The purpose of this part is to: (1) Establish a supportive housing special fund to be administered by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation; (2)

administered by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation; (2) Appropriate funds to support the development, operation, and maintenance of supportive housing, as well as the provision of supportive services; and (3) Establish, within the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation, one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I

corporation, one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help with the administration of the supportive housing special fund. SECTION 4. Chapter 201H, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding a new subpart to part III to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " .

be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " . Supportive Housing Special Fund §201H- Supportive housing special fund. (a) There is established a supportive housing special fund to be administered by the corporation for the purpose of developing, operating, and maintaining affordable, permanent housing and the provision of supportive

and maintaining affordable, permanent housing and the provision of supportive services for individuals or families with special needs. (b) Moneys in the fund may be used to: (1) Make loans to finance the development, pre-development, construction, acquisition, preservation, or substantial rehabilitation of supportive housing projects; (2) Make project-based rental assistance

rehabilitation of supportive housing projects; (2) Make project-based rental assistance payments; (3) Make payments for supportive services for households residing in the supportive housing projects; and (4) For other housing services or activities as provided in rules adopted by the corporation without regard to chapter 91. (c) The fund may

corporation without regard to chapter 91. (c) The fund may include sums appropriated by the legislature, private contributions, proceeds from repayment of loans, interest, fees, other returns, and moneys from other sources. (d) An amount from the fund, to be set by the corporation and authorized by the legislature, may

set by the corporation and authorized by the legislature, may be used for administrative expenses incurred by the corporation in administering the fund; provided that moneys in the fund shall not be used to finance day-to-day administrative expenses of the projects allotted moneys from the fund. (e) The corporation shall

projects allotted moneys from the fund. (e) The corporation shall consult with the counties and community-based organizations to leverage funds and obtain input on selection of projects. (f) The corporation may contract with other executive branch departments or agencies, the counties, or private or nonprofit organizations as necessary for the

counties, or private or nonprofit organizations as necessary for the provision of supportive housing and services. The corporation shall be exempt from chapter 103D in selecting a qualified private or nonprofit organization to assist with the development and maintenance of supportive housing and provision of rental assistance and supportive services.

supportive housing and provision of rental assistance and supportive services. The corporation may, without regard to chapter 91, establish rules and qualification standards for participants of the supportive housing program. (g) The corporation may establish, revise, charge, and collect a reasonable service fee, as necessary, in connection with its financing,

reasonable service fee, as necessary, in connection with its financing, services, and approvals under this subpart. The fees shall be deposited into the supportive housing special fund. (h) The corporation shall submit a report to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of each regular session

twenty days prior to the convening of each regular session describing the projects funded using moneys from the supportive housing special fund. §201H- Additional powers. The powers conferred upon the corporation by this subpart shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law, and nothing

to the powers conferred by any other law, and nothing in this subpart shall be construed as limiting any powers, rights, privileges, or immunities conferred." SECTION 5 . There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as

Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 to be deposited into the supportive housing special fund. SECTION 6 . There is appropriated out of

special fund. SECTION 6 . There is appropriated out of the supportive housing special fund the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 to be expended

may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 to be expended as follows: (1) $ for the financing of the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services for households with special needs who reside in the supportive housing projects ; and (2) $

numbers_data.text: 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure

legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the

extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.

BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate

The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui

with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered,

on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session

county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session

pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to

$5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically

developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units

was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment,

unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of

for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time-limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long-term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among

targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the important principles of the State's kauhale initiative is building partnerships between government and community, providing affordable spaces for housing and healing, and fostering belonging and responsibility. Every kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding

a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. in which some or all the units are targeted to special needs individuals or families who require supportive services; and (3) Appropriate funds to assist the statewide office of homelessness and housing solutions to implement the kauhale initiative.
